issue.title: Maximum time to expand globs
issue.body:
There should be a setting for max time to expand globs, and an error if glob expansion takes longer than the setting.
Default should be one minute.
See #5966 for background about why.
Low difficulty for only emitting an error if the max was exceeded.
Medium difficulty to also stop expanding the glob when the max is exceeded, i.e. for it to be a timeout.
As a follow up issue, to be created after this is completed, coala should stop processing only effected sections, and continue processing unaffected sections.  Thus is needs to determine which sections would be effected by the glob.

issue.title: Write dev docs about testing a coala change on all bears

A coala change often needs to be tested against bears.
To do this, the coala-bears CI needs to be instructed to install the coala PR, so that the bears CI can show the effect of the coala change.

issue.title: Report debug messages during glob expansion
issue.body:
coala appears to hang whenever a glob takes a long time to expand.
This happens very frequently when it descends into node_modules/ .  There are other bugs about coala behaving better when descending a node_modules/, but typically nobody wants it to descend node_modules/, so this should be an error.
There should be regular debug messages during a glob expansion, including when they appear in files = .. and ignore = ...

issue.title: Create a line length test helper
issue.body:
A line length test helper will take a chunk of source , and a regex, and verify the bear accepts source under the line length and rejects lines over the line length.
The max_line_length setting can be automatically determined by the lines in the source provided by the caller.  The bear should pass this test.
The regex is then used to increase the size of the source line lengths by 1 character, in accordance with the source language rules.
The helper confirms that the source was increased by 1 character only, and re-runs the bear, and expects it to fail.

issue.title: Support Python 3.4.x
issue.body:
Python 3.4.0-3 were dropped because of 8a08cd2, due to Python <3.4.4 not having asyncio.run_coroutine_threadsafe.  This has only happened in the current dev release.
However package trollius provides that on Python 2.7+
Python 3.4.3 is used as the Trusty default, so supporting it has benefit to users and especially to CI which uses that by default for all non-Python languages.
It also means the platform requirements of 0.11 will continue to be supported by the next release.

issue.title: verify_local_bear: Add base directory argument
issue.body:
Some linters expect to have some additional files in the base directory where it is invoked.
verify_local_bear needs an optional argument to supply this directory, and then change into that directory while running the bear.
coala_utils 's ContextManagers.change_directory may be useful for this.

issue.title: Missing attributes for CSS language definition
Add linter bear type 'json'
issue.body:
Many linters now emit json, and we have regular bugs when a linter is emitting json but also emits an error message on stdout.
The loading of the json can be done in coala with appropriate error checking and logging of any problems.
Also if the json is empty, the bear .run doesnt need to be invoked.

issue.title: Expand ruby language definition
issue.body:
The ruby language definition in coala is empty.
coala should have at least a basic language file for ruby.
There are quite a few concepts in Ruby which can not be correctly described using the limited coala language concepts, especially % string literals and balanced delimiters.

issue.title: Add a note to reviewers
issue.body:
Add "Check that the changes haven't been pushed from master branch" as a note to reviewers in the reviewing guide.
The wording needs to be clear enough to convey that this isn't mandatory (so that reviewers don't advice newcomers to close even their mergeable good PRs) and is just a good practice.
label: difficulty/newcomer

issue.title: .coafile not showing the correct error
issue.body:
An earlier typo in .coafile which is being fixed by #5043 doesn't show the correct error message. Instead it shows an error based on the previous line
eg. if your .coafile has this
use_spaces = true
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

it will show
 Unable to convert parameter 'use_spaces' into type <class 'bool'>.

if your .coafile is
files = *.txt
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

It will show Unable to find that file/ No matching file
or if your .coafile is
bears = SpaceConsistencyBear
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

it will show
No bears matching 'SpaceConsistencyBear
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction' were found. Make sure you have coala-bears installed or you have typed the name correctly.

Instead it should point out the error in the statement itself

Okay now what I meant with considering all cases is that the bear might really refer to a line/column that doesn't exist. comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,85 @@
+Testing coala change on coala-bears
+===================================
+
+When large changes are made to the coala core, they should be tested
+on the coala-bears to confirm that they work as expected and don't
+break anything on the bears' side.
+
+There was an attempt to automate this through
+https://github.com/coala/coala/pull/4424 which used to depend upon docker
+image, but unfortunately the image breaks stuff for now.
+
+But we can still do it manually, by changing the coala dependency for the
+bears to be the one consisting of the changes made For which we need to create
+a new branch on coala-bears, edit the requirements and run it on CI.
+
+Set-up a new testing branch
+---------------------------
+
+Assuming we have already made changes to coala through a new branch, we can
+use the branch to install coala instead of master by editing requirements.txt
+file in coala-bears. So, lets set-up a new branch on coala-bears for these
+changes.
+
+If you have not already, clone your fork by running:
+
+::
+
+    $ git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/coala-bears
+
+Make sure that you replace <your-username> with your corresponding github
+username.
+
+Now, navigate to the directory where coala-bears is located.
+
+::
+
+    $ cd coala-bears
+
+Before making any change, switch to a new branch (other than master).
+
+::
+
+    $ git checkout -b new_test_branch
+
+.. note::
+    Never make any changes on your master branch.
+    See `Git Tutorial <https://coala.io/gitbasics>`_ for more info.
+
+Now you've done that, you are free to make changes.
+
+Change coala dependency in requirements.txt
+-------------------------------------------
+
+First thing we need is to change the coala dependency.
+
+Now assuming you have made changes to coala fork on branch <branch-name>, you
+can edit the coala dependency by changing the corresponding line to:
+
+::
+
+    git+https://github.com/<your-username>/coala@<branch-name>#egg=coala
+
+Set-up CI to run on your branch
+-------------------------------
+
+Since you need the tests to be ran on CI, set it up by modifying respective
+configuration files. You can have a look at our
+`CI Tutorial <https://api.coala.io/en/latest/Developers/Adding_CI.html>`_.
+for more info.
+
+For example, to run `travis-ci <https://travis-ci.org/>`_ on your
+branch you could modify .travis.yml file. At the end of the file, you'll find
+branch specification where you could white-list your branch name. So you should
+have the change as following:
+
+::
+
+    branches:
+      only:
+        - new_test_branch
+
+Simillarly, you can make changes to appveyor.yml file to run tests on AppveyorCI

@@ -0,0 +1,101 @@
+Testing changes to coala on coala-bears
+=======================================
+
+When large changes are made to the coala core, they should be tested
+on the coala-bears to confirm that they work as expected and don't
+break anything on the bears' side.
+
+You can do this by changing the coala dependency for the bears to
+be the one consisting of the changes. In order to do this, you need to create
+a new branch on coala-bears, update the coala requirement to point to your
+changes and run CI on it.
+
+Set up a new testing branch
+---------------------------
+
+Assuming you have already made changes to coala through a new branch, you can
+use that branch to install coala by editing requirements.txt in coala-bears.
+Let's set-up a new branch on coala-bears for these changes:
+
+If you have not already, clone the coala-bears repository by running:
+
+::
+
+    $ git clone -o upstream https://github.com/coala/coala-bears
+
+.. note::
+    ``-o upstream`` sets the remote name of the original coala-bears repository
+    as upstream.
+
+Now, navigate to the directory where coala-bears is located.
+
+::
+
+    $ cd coala-bears
+
+This tutorial assumes you are working on your own fork. To fork the repository,
+go to the official repository of coala-bears and click on the ``Fork``
+button from the website interface. To add it locally, simply run:
+
+::
+
+    $ git remote add myfork fork_link
+
+where ``myfork`` is the name of your fork, and ``fork_link`` is a link to your
+fork repository.
+
+Before making any change, switch to a new branch.
+
+::
+
+    $ git checkout -b new_test_branch
+
+Here ``new_test_branch`` is the name of the new branch you created. You can
+use any name you want for this purpose.
+
+.. note::
+    Never make any changes on your master branch.
+    Please go through our `Newcomers Guide <https://coala.io/newcomer>`_ if
+    you are new to coala.
+
+Now that you're on a new branch, you are free to make changes.
+
+Change coala dependency in requirements.txt
+-------------------------------------------
+
+First, you need to change the coala dependency.
+
+Now, assuming you have made changes to coala fork on branch ``<branch-name>``,

+---------------------------

+use that branch to install coala by editing requirements.txt in coala-bears.
+Let's set-up a new branch on coala-bears for these changes:
+
+If you have not already, clone the coala-bears repository by running:
+

+
+    $ git clone -o upstream https://github.com/coala/coala-bears
+
+.. note::
+    ``-o upstream`` sets the remote name of the original coala-bears repository
+    as upstream.
+
+Now, navigate to the directory where coala-bears is located.
+
+::
+
+    $ cd coala-bears
+
+This tutorial assumes you are working on your own fork. To fork the repository,
+go to the official repository of coala-bears and click on the ``Fork``
+button from the website interface. To add it locally, simply run:
+
+::
+
+    $ git remote add myfork fork_link
+
+where ``myfork`` is the name of your fork, and ``fork_link`` is a link to your
+fork repository.
+
+Before making any change, switch to a new branch.
+
+::
+
+    $ git checkout -b new_test_branch
+
+Here ``new_test_branch`` is the name of the new branch you created. You can
+use any name you want for this purpose.
+
+.. note::
+    Never make any changes on your master branch.
+    Please go through our `Newcomers Guide <https://coala.io/newcomer>`_ if
+    you are new to coala.
+
+Now that you're on a new branch, you are free to make changes.
+
+Change coala dependency in requirements.txt
+-------------------------------------------
+
+First, you need to change the coala dependency.
+
+Now, assuming you have made changes to coala fork on branch ``<branch-name>``,
+you can edit the coala dependency by editing requirements.txt in coala-bears.
+To do this, you need to edit the line in requirements.txt corresponding to:
+::
+
+    git+https://github.com/coala/coala#egg=coala
+
+and change it to :
+
+::
+
+    git+https://github.com/<your-username>/coala@<branch-name>#egg=coala
+
+This will ensure that the coala will be installed using the source from the
+branch consisting of your changes to coala.
+
+Commit and push changes
+-----------------------
+
+You have now made the required changes to the bears repository, you are free
+to commit the changes and push the branch.

issue.title: Python 3.4.3 support
issue.body:
Closes #5891
Sits on top of #5893

comments.bodyText: Why is 3.4.3 not here?

it would slow down all builds, unnecessarily.
We could add it to master builds.
Or I think we can also only run jobs on the nightly cron, which would reduce delays if multiple PRs are getting merged.

What is the benefit of using moban to copy async.py from https://github.com/NAStools/homeassistant/blob/master/homeassistant/util/async.py? That project seems to be out of maintenance.
Drawbacks I can see:

licence is not stated in async.py, but in this file.
async.py needs to be excluded in .coafile.
async.py has other functions, e.g. fire_coroutine_threadsafe, which we don't use.
We cannot easily test it.
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -65,3 +67,6 @@ targets:
   - netlify.toml: docs/netlify.toml
   - .misc/appveyor.yml: ci/appveyor.yml.jj2
   - .misc/run_with_env.cmd: run_with_env.cmd
+copy:
+  # homeassistant license MIT
+  - coalib/misc/Asyncio.py: async.py

comments.bodyText:
The reason to do it this way is so that external code is 'managed'.  We can improve the way it is managed by improving moban.
Your point '3' is the only significant problem, and that can be solved by moban having patch support, so we can exclude the other code e.g. moremoban/moban#75 . A header can also be added using a patch.
I am not worried about the licensing being missing from the file, as anyone modifying this file will likely be informed via code review, or will be reverted when someone looks at the moban job.  We should distribute the MIT license, and any other license of code we're including, but by no means is this "substantial portions" according to the MIT license so we're not breaking the license by not including it.  And by having a control file which mentions where code came from, and thus were the license text can be found, we're not hiding the fact the code is copied.
The fact it is unmaintained is a problem for the future, as PRs upstream will not get merged.  Again, a .patch could solve that, but i would expect that this type of code would be moved to a new coala-compat package, or something like that, or a sub-module of coala-utils.
Same with the .coafile problems.  A patch can fix it.
The drawbacks of not doing it:

another piece of copied code will fade into the coala codebase and its history effectively lost
coala doesnt have a process for allowing externally written code into the repo.
moban doesnt have a user (coala) pushing for it to handle more complicated scenarios than just 'copy'.
coala doesnt start the process of identifying and fixing any existing copied code.  This one is MIT, but we will likely find some which isnt so freely licensed.  e.g. we have CC-BY-SA-licensed 'code' in some repos, and a major issue over in coala-quickstart
etc.

Being in .moban.yaml is an annoyance.  That is intentional ;-)

issue.title: Do not error hard because a dependency of a bear has been updated
issue.body:
Currently, upon a simple load of bears, we implicitly check every single dependency to see if it's exactly as any given bear hard pins to antequated versions and fail hard if you are even slightly off. I don't see a reason this should be the case as this is Python; it's not coala's concern whether I've installed a later isort version than it expects, especially not at runtime.
This simple fix merely resolves each entrypoint instead, which is really what we're trying to do anyway.

comments.bodyText:
Hi, if you want to contribute to coala, the best way is to follow coala's contribution guide. http://api.coala.io/en/latest/Developers/Newcomers_Guide.html That is, you'd better create an issue first, describe what improvement you want, get assigned and then work on it.
btw load() function doesn't have argument 'require'.
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -452,7 +452,9 @@ def collect_registered_bears_dirs(entrypoint):
     for ep in pkg_resources.iter_entry_points(entrypoint):
         registered_package = None
         try:
-            registered_package = ep.load()
+            # backwards compat with old setuptools that do not provide Entrypoint.resolve
+            meth = getattr(ep, 'resolve', functools.partial(ep.load, require=False))

Nice solution, but the last line of the commit message needs to refer to an issue, not the same PR.
I suggest using "Related to #4085" or "Related to #3545" as the two closest open issues to the problem that you are solving.
Or you can create a new issue about it.
Then, the other problem with this lovely hack is we need to know what is the minimum version of setuptools/pkg_resources where this hack works.
What would be really nice (but not mandatory) is if this little hack was packaged up in a separate repo & pypi package with its own CI to ensure it keeps working with new releases of setuptools.

As for the minimum version, it would work on at the very least but not
limited to the same versions as before, since it falls back took the
original behavior.

I do agree it would be nice to have automated detection of external API
usage breakage in some manner or another in some version of our future.

This gets rather messy to find the lowest version of setuptools, as pkg_resources uses vendored packaging for the code in question, and to make matters worse distros then do unvendoring, so there are a variety of packaging versions to consider for distro based installs, and a variety of setuptools versions to consider for pypi based installs.
I think we should create a separate issue about it, and work on it after this is merged.  We do know that this works, albeit we have no tests to confirm it.
https://pypi.org/project/entrypoints/ might be helpful.

issue.title: SASS.py: Add language definition for SASS
issue.body:
Closes #5740

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!
